results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 171]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film features the Gadsden family life in the 1950s both at home and on outings to a sports club and to the beach. The children are shown at several different ages. This film also showcases some wonderful examples of the clothing styles of the era for both children and adults.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 young boy of the family playing in the home garden, hosing the garden and having a ‘piggy back’ ride with dad
00:01:05:00 dad in a suit, saying goodbye to his son and about to leave in a car
00:02:00:00 the reel changes to colour and three older members of the family or friends are dressed in wintry, quite formal clothes. The older couple could be a set of grandparents. Anther woman wears a jodhpurs and jacket outfit which was popular at the time for women during outdoor activities.
00:02:17:00 wonderful images of dad and small son in matching check shirts and the little boy is playing on a trike
00:03:54:00 a new baby is introduced to the camera
00:04:31:00 Ronald Gadsden swimming in a pool that is in a bush setting and with a large ‘Private Pool’ sign. Later scenes indicate that this may be part of a sports club.
00:05:10:00 shows us a large garden with tables which could be the grounds of a club where members are enjoying beers and one of the children having what appears to be a ‘lemon squash’.
00:06:25:00 begins a sequence of beach scenes including the family exploring a cave
00:07:15:00 a baby on an air mattress and being dangled in the water on the shoreline
00:09:13:00 the baby sitting up in a high chair in a great example of an infant dress with ‘smocking’ detail across the front
00:09:58:00 Jess Gadsden with the children when they are a bit older, playing with trikes and a toy ride on car in home driveway
00:15:17:00 more scenes at the beach with other members of the extended family or friends and their children
00:15:59:00 great examples of 1950s beachcoats and caps worn by women at the beach as well as men’s swimming trunks and women’s bathers. The reel ends with views of the baby in a swimsuit with shirring and frills on the back, typical of the era.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 168]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows downhill, cross-country and slalom skiing at Mt Buller, Victoria, including the Women’s National Ski Competition in August 1947 and 1948 (according to notes on the donated original film can). There are good views including a horse drawn sled, snow fashion of the era and a ski lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Some of the footage is overexposed.

Selected highlights list
00:00:02:00 downhill ski race, various competitors filmed from a fixed camera position
00:02:40:00 views of snowed covered mountains
00:02:50:00 skiers in distance going downhill, possible slalom
00:03:46:00 better footage of downhill slalom
00:04:36:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis, views of mountain and ski lodge
00:04:49:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis
00:04:58:00 good footage of horse drawn sled
00:05:06:00 skiers walking wearing skis
00:06:50:00 group cross country skiing with sled
00:06:58:00 man strapped to sled (possibly injured or practising)
00:07:08:00 man gets off sled at ski lodge amid group of skiers
00:07:17:00 close up views of skiers at lodge showing fashions of the era
00:07:35:00 people riding horse drawn sled
00:07:44:00 downhill skiing
00:08:32:00 dining room in ski lodge full of diners (waitress in uniform)
00:09:03:00 mountain views
00:09:40:00 horse riding
00:10:38:00 man standing by car loaded with skis

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 164]
results.brief_description:

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens enjoying the snow at Mount Buller in Victoria and particularly features children.

This film was originally shot on 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:56:00 Jess and one of the chicldren skiing
00:05:35:00 a competition for children

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 157]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows us the wedding of Gwen, one of the Gadsden family.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 women walking through the garden, dressed-up and smiling at the camera (these are presumably wedding guests arriving)
00:00:19:00 a close up of the bride in a blue wedding dress
00:00:21:00 the following 20 seconds or so of footage is badly under-exposed and very little action can be distinguished
00:00:42:00 the bride and groom pose in front of the church
00:00:54:00 the following 10 seconds or so of footage is badly under-exposed and very little action can be distinguished
00:01:05:00 we see the bride and groom, now dressed in casual clothes, loading-up and settling into a car with a full trailer attached (the car is a distinctive model Ford). Eventually the car drives off, heading through the metal gates of the garden, with the pair smiling and waving at the camera.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 152]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This short film shows small yachts sailing on Port Phillip Bay near Frankston, Victoria in 1969. Teams of 3 are shown sailing small wooden yachts and possibly racing. Some beach scenes are included.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Much of the footage of the sailing is overexposed and slightly out of focus.

This film shows yachts sailing around a spot in (most probably) Port Phillip Bay and a school swimming competition.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

00:04:39:00 boats and yachts berthed on the sand

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 133]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. The first shows downhill skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. The second, a sports day at ‘Glamorgan’ kindergarten, now the Melbourne ‘prep’ campus of Geelong Grammar.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00 skiing downhill past camera
00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 122]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the family at the New South Wales coastal town of Eden, in 1938.

Opens with shots of small, masted boats in harbour (at Eden, New South Wales). One of the boats – with four men in it – is moving out of harbour under engine power.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 a pier, with vehicular rails running along it and a small two-chimneyed ship moored alongside. A small masted vessel is being prepared for launching
00:00:43:00 close-up of a man striding through the camera’s field of vision, then the camera pans slowly over the sea and coastal landscape
00:01:28:00 a bush-fringed road, with a parked car and a man sitting nearby (with back to camera). The camera lingers on the surrounding bush and hills, with the sea visible in the background. This sequence appears to be shot from a vantage point further inland than the earlier coastal scenes
00:01:57:00 two people are standing at the base of a tall building; the camera pans up the structure to show the ‘battlements’ at its top. This is ‘Boyd’s Tower’, a 23 metre structure built in 1847 by the ex-Scottish entrepreneur Ben Boyd, intended as a lighthouse, but never commissioned.
00:02:20:00 entire tower photographed from a slight distance; the full structure can be seen above the surrounding bush
00:02:37:00 same man who appeared earlier in the footage and a woman wearing riding jodhpurs are standing on a rise overlooking the water as the camera pans past them across the scene of bush and sea
00:03:06:00 same man and woman – accompanied by an older woman – are strolling through a park or garden above the coast, looking away from the camera. A dog is frolicking around them, and a horse is grazing nearby.
00:03:24:0 same man walking along a rise, looking away from the camera at the sea and headlands below him. The camera tracks him as he walks further away from it, looking back over his shoulder occasionally.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 121]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow
